MIPS Multi-Cycle Simulator Support Classes

See:
          Description

Packages
MIPS_Multi  

 

MIPS Multi-Cycle Simulator Support Classes

This package provides three classes to support development of a simulator for the MIPS multi-cycle CPU developed in Chapter 5 of Computer Organization and Design, 3rd Edition by David Patterson and John Hennessy: Memory, Registers, and Loader. In addition, there is a main() method in class MIPS_Multi that I used to verify that the classes work. Finally, there is a Utils class which, at this point, contains a single method that can be used to format 32-bit integers as 8-character hexadecimal strings for printing.

To write your own simulator, you can either create another class with your own main() method in it, or you can simply edit the main method in class MIPS_Multi. (Using the former technique means you don’t need to extract my classes from the supplied Jar file if you don’t want to.) Your job is two write ten methods, one for each state in Figure 5.38 in the text. Your main() method would then look something like this:

  for (String arg : args)
  {
    if (Loader.loadLogFile(arg))
    {
      state_0();
    }
  }

This example assumes that you named your ten methods state_0, state_1, etc., and that they are all static methods defined in the same class as your main() method.
